title: 110_hr6804
content: The "Families and Small Business Energy Tax Relief Act of 2008" includes a temporary refundable credit against income tax for natural gas, heating oil, and propane costs of individuals. The "Families and Small Business Energy Tax Relief Act of 2008" offers a credit for residential energy costs to individuals, capped at $750 ($1,500 for joint returns), with a reduction based on income levels. The "Families and Small Business Energy Tax Relief Act of 2008" provides a credit for residential energy costs, with a maximum of $10,000 ($20,000 for joint returns). Adjusted gross income is calculated without considering certain sections. Residential energy costs include payments for natural gas, heating oil, or propane for the taxpayer's main residence. The term "principal residence" is defined as per section 121. The term 'heating season' refers to September through March. Special rules exclude fuel used in residences outside the US or not the taxpayer's main residence during the heating season. Amounts paid for natural gas under a level payment plan are considered for the portion of the heating season they cover. The section applies to homeowners associations, members, and tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations. The credit allowed is treated as a refundable credit. The section applies to amounts paid or incurred during 2008 or 2009. Conforming amendments include adding section 6431 to paragraph (2) of title 31, United States Code. The table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65 of the Code is amended by adding a new item. SEC. 6431 provides a temporary refundable credit against income tax for natural gas, heating oil, and propane costs of individuals, effective for taxable years ending after December 31, 2007. SEC. 3 introduces a temporary credit for small businesses, farmers, and fishermen to offset high fuel costs under section 45Q of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The fuel cost credit under section 38 allows a 15 percent credit for expenses on creditable fuel used in farming, commercial fishing, or by small businesses meeting the gross receipts test of section 448(c). The fuel cost credit under section 38 allows a 15 percent credit for expenses on creditable fuel such as gasoline, diesel fuel, heating oil, propane, and natural gas. This section applies to amounts paid or incurred during 2008 or 2009. Conforming amendments to section 38(b) of the Code include adding the fuel cost credit as a new provision. The table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code is amended to include a new item after section 45P. "Sec. 45Q. Temporary credit for small businesses, farmers, and fishermen to offset high fuel costs. Effective Date: Amendments apply to taxable years ending after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4. Modifications of credit for nonbusiness energy property." The amendment to Section 25C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 makes the credit for qualified oil furnaces permanent and increases the credit amount for qualified oil furnaces to $1,500. The lifetime limitation for the credit is also increased to $4,000. The amendment to Section 25C of the Internal Revenue Code increases the credit percentage for building envelope components from 10 percent to 25 percent. The effective date for these amendments is after the date of enactment of the Act, with a specific provision for property placed in service after December 31, 2007. SEC. 5. OUTREACH AND WEATHERIZATION ASSISTANCE. Section 2605 of the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Act of 1981 is amended to authorize additional appropriations for outreach and weatherization activities. $204,000,000 is allocated for outreach activities and $766,000,000 for weatherization and repair activities annually. No other funds from this title can be used for these activities in a fiscal year with appropriations under this subsection.
